INDIANA UNIVERSITY
BLOOMINGTON, INDIANA
RADIO BUILDING
AREA CODE 812
TEL. NO.
September 30, 1963
Enthusiasm for the rapidly approaching Conference
for Midwest Educational Broadcast Music Directors is
becoming harder to contain here at WFIU, and we would
like to pass on some of the reasons why.
As you know, the Conference is set for October 22
and 23 on the Indiana University campus which, at that
time, should be a lavish Autumn spectacle,
A significant event will be the premiere performance
of "Quintet for Oboe and Strings--1963n by Bernhard
Heiden, Professor of Composition at Indiana University.
The work was written to celebrate the opening of the new
$2,500,000 Radio-TV Production Center. The featured
soloist will be Jerry Sirucek, who came to the music
faculty from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, Last
spring Heiden saw his first opera, The Darkened City,
premiered by the Indiana University Opera Theater. His
work is not only familiar to our campus, but has been
performed by many of the jnajor symphony orchestras and
chamber groups in America,
Also to be heard are quartets by the Chilean composer,
Juan Orrego Salas, who now heads the Latin American Music
Center here, and Thomas Beversdorf, resident composer*
Oprego Salas’s work, commissioned for the 1957 Inter-
American Festival, was premiered in Washington, D, C, by
the Julliard Quartett The quartet by Beversdorf was
composed in 1952 andhas been performed several times
throughout the country. The Berkshire Quartet which
winters In Indiana and summers on Music Mountain Is the
performing group and includes Urico Rossi, first violin;
Albert Lazan, second violin; David Dawson, viola; and
Fritz Maag, cello.
Our key speaker, hopefully, will be Samuel Chotzlnoff,
General Music Director of the National Broadcasting Company.
We say hopefully because Mr, Chotzlnoff, although enthused
about the invitation and especially eager to see the Music
Sohool, is presently recovering from an illness. The
prospects of his appearance, however, are bright.
"Tympani and Tape’* is the title of a workshop to
be given by George Gabor, widely recorded percussionist
and campus wit, and Louis R. Burroughs, Vice President
of Broadcast and Recording Equipment of Electro-Voice, Inc,
